displayed_text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession?

answer.text_box: I think it’s a lazy way to make a living since they spend very little time online in regards to the amount of money they may possible make.  Also, think it’s a bit narcissistic. Calling it a profession is a real joke to me.

displayed_text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Sentiment split: roughly 34% favorable, 21% unfavorable, and 44% mixed/conditional.
  • Supportive views: Many see influencing as a legitimate, modern profession that democratizes opportunity, enables entrepreneurship and remote work, and provides entertainment, product discovery, and even alternative news. Several note its role in reshaping advertising, challenging legacy media, and expanding who can succeed in the creative economy.
  • Concerns and criticisms: Common worries include inauthenticity/fakery, grifting, misinformation, overconsumption, and saturation. Several fear unhealthy role-modeling for kids and the “easy money” narrative, loss of originality, parasocial dynamics, and the gap between top earners and most creators. Many highlight volatility, luck, and sustainability challenges; some feel it should be a side gig rather than a primary career for most.
  • News and information role: A sizable group sees influencers as supplementing or replacing traditional news and TV, sometimes for the better; others warn against relying on them exclusively or uncritically, citing echo chambers and misinformation risks.
  • Professional norms and guardrails: Frequent calls for accountability, transparency (especially around ads and AI), authenticity, media literacy, and in some cases regulation, fair contracts, unions, and mental-health support. Many accept it as a profession if creators behave responsibly and put in real work.
  • Trends noted: Rapid growth during the pandemic, migration across platforms (YouTube to TikTok/Instagram), increasing competition, and the continued blurring of lines between entertainment, marketing, and news.

Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Sentiment split: roughly 34% favorable, 21% unfavorable, and 44% mixed/conditional.
  • Supportive views: Many see influencing as a legitimate, modern profession that democratizes opportunity, enables entrepreneurship and remote work, and provides entertainment, product discovery, and even alternative news. Several note its role in reshaping advertising, challenging legacy media, and expanding who can succeed in the creative economy.
  • Concerns and criticisms: Common worries include inauthenticity/fakery, grifting, misinformation, overconsumption, and saturation. Several fear unhealthy role-modeling for kids and the “easy money” narrative, loss of originality, parasocial dynamics, and the gap between top earners and most creators. Many highlight volatility, luck, and sustainability challenges; some feel it should be a side gig rather than a primary career for most.
  • News and information role: A sizable group sees influencers as supplementing or replacing traditional news and TV, sometimes for the better; others warn against relying on them exclusively or uncritically, citing echo chambers and misinformation risks.
  • Professional norms and guardrails: Frequent calls for accountability, transparency (especially around ads and AI), authenticity, media literacy, and in some cases regulation, fair contracts, unions, and mental-health support. Many accept it as a profession if creators behave responsibly and put in real work.
  • Trends noted: Rapid growth during the pandemic, migration across platforms (YouTube to TikTok/Instagram), increasing competition, and the continued blurring of lines between entertainment, marketing, and news.

Summary B

Based on the comments provided, here is an overall summary:

There is a wide spectrum of opinions on internet influencers becoming a recognized profession, with views ranging from strong support to significant criticism, and many holding a nuanced perspective.

A notable portion of comments expressed positive views, seeing the profession as a valid and modern way to earn a living. Supporters appreciate that it allows individuals to pursue their passions, work flexibly, and create opportunities for themselves. Influencers are often valued for providing entertainment, useful information, and relatable product recommendations. Some view them as a natural evolution of media, democratizing fame and serving as the "new media houses" that are more accessible and down-to-earth than traditional celebrities or news outlets.

Conversely, a significant number of comments conveyed negative sentiment. A primary criticism revolves around a perceived lack of authenticity, with many describing influencers as annoying, fake, or attention-seeking. Concerns were raised about their societal impact, including the promotion of overconsumption, the spread of misinformation, and the creation of a homogenous culture where individuality is lost. Some feel the profession gives young people unrealistic expectations about success and discourages them from pursuing traditional education or careers. The oversaturation of the field and the need for creators to be increasingly outrageous to gain attention were also cited as drawbacks.

Many participants took a more analytical and balanced stance. They acknowledge influencing as a legitimate, though difficult, profession that requires significant work, creativity, and business acumen. These comments often compare it to other jobs in the entertainment industry, seeing it as a modern offshoot. A recurring theme in this middle ground is the call for responsibility and accountability. Many believe that due to their impact on audiences, influencers should be held to higher standards of transparency and integrity, similar to other professions. While recognizing the opportunities it creates, these comments also highlight the risks, such as the potential for misuse of platforms and the precarious nature of a career dependent on algorithms and audience engagement.
